BIOS770
Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc in Drug Discovery. It is a bespoke core module for the programme. There are no other suitable modules available.

Overview

Overview
This module explores how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the drug discovery landscape, enabling faster and more efficient identification of novel therapeutics. It provides an in-depth understanding of the integration of AI techniques with biological data to accelerate various stages of drug discovery, from target identification to lead optimisation and clinical trials. The module covers the latest AI-driven approaches and tools used to analyse complex biological datasets, predict drug efficacy and safety, and optimise drug candidates. Through a combination of theoretical learning and practical applications, students will gain the skills to apply AI in real-world drug discovery projects. The module is assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Educational Aims
To provide students with comprehensive knowledge of how AI can accelerate drug discovery including improvements in efficiency, accuracy, cost-effectiveness and integration with biological data.

To equip students with the practical skills needed to apply AI techniques in different stages of the drug discovery pipeline.

To engage students with current research and advancements in AI-driven drug discovery, enabling them to explore potential challenges and opportunities
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module explores how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the drug discovery landscape, enabling faster and more efficient identification of novel therapeutics. It provides an in-depth understanding of the integration of AI techniques with biological data to accelerate various stages of drug discovery, from target identification to lead optimisation and clinical trials. The module is taught through a mixture of lectures and workshops and assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Outline Syllabus
Brief recap of AI in Drug Discovery and the role of AI in accelerating drug discovery.

Introduction to machine learning and AI techniques relevant to biology.
- AI in Target Identification and Validation
- Computational methods for target identification (e.g., genomics, proteomics).
- Case studies on successful AI applications in target discovery.

Brief recap of AI in Lead Discovery (covered in prerequisit module CHEM521)

AI approaches for optimising pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties. including ADMET (Absorption, Distribution, Metabolism, Excretion, Toxicity) predictions.

Predicting off-target effects and drug safety using AI.

AI for Predicting Drug Efficacy and Safety

AI-driven preclinical and clinical trial predictions.

Integrating AI with Bioinformatics

Bioinformatics pipelines enhanced by AI.

Multi-omics data integration and analysis using AI.

Personalised medicine and precision drug discovery through AI.

Ethical, Legal, and Regulatory Considerations in AI-driven drug discovery.
- Regulatory frameworks for AI applications in drug development.
- Data privacy, intellectual property, and AI in drug discovery.

Current Research and Future Directions
- Emerging trends in AI-driven drug discovery.
- The future of AI in accelerating drug development.
- Group discussions on current research articles.

This module will build on material delivered in CHEM521. The content above will be delivered in 16 lectures, with the students able to access lecture material and reading lists through the VLE. Students will be expected to utilise the reading list to supplement the lecture knowledge in order to complete the mini-project that will be developed through the supplementary workshops and assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures: 16 hr

Topics will be delivered in 1 hr lectures to deliver the underlying knowledge on to tackle the chemical data scenarios developed in the practical workshops. Delivered by staff research active in this area - research connected teaching.

Workshops: 5 x 3 hr

Workshops will be used to give students practical experience in applying the concepts covered in the lectures to a variety of biological related drug discovery concepts (Liverpool Curriculum framework - digital fluency and active learning). The workshops will include elements of data retrieval and curation and the implementation of methods for data analysis and their critical evaluation and will facilitate the production of the various assessment elements.

A typical week will consist of 2 lectures with a workshop taking place every 2-3 weeks.
Delivery and assessment will involve multiple methods, recordings of lectures will be available to ensure inclusivity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
5 assessments - students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. A semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline:

Problem Definition and Target Selection Report (15%):

Task: Identify a biological target (e.g., a protein, gene, or pathway) for drug discovery.

Output: A report detailing the chosen target, the rationale behind its selection, and a summary of the relevant biological pathways involved in the disease.

Data Collection and Preprocessing Summary (20%):

Task: Gather and preprocess relevant biological data (e.g., genomic, proteomic, or chemical structure data) required for the AI model.

Output: A detailed description of the data sources, preprocessing steps taken, and the final dataset prepared for analysis.

AI Model Development Report (25%):

Task: Develop and implement an AI model (e.g., machine learning or deep learning) to predict drug-target interactions, identify potential lead compounds, or optimise lead candidates based on the biological data.

Output: A technical report outlining the model development process, including the choice of algorithm, feature selection, model training, and validation. The report should include how they would establish performance metrics and a discussion of model accuracy and limitations.

Lead Optimisation and Validation Report (20%):

Task: Use the AI model to optimise the lead compound for improved efficacy, safety, and drug-like properties. Validate the predicted outcomes using either computational techniques or existing experimental data.

Output: A comprehensive analysis of the optimised lead compounds, including a comparison with initial candidates and a discussion of the predicted ADMET properties.

Final Presentation (20%):

Output: Give a 10-15 minute presentation on the pipeline

Due to the mini-project based nature of the assessments and the need for consistent feedback and the ability to check this has been acted on the written assessments can not be anonymous. Presentation cannot be marked anonymously.

Standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy – the format of the resit opportunity is the same but different data/question is used, capped at 50% and will take place in the normal reassessment window.

5 points of assessment – development of the final model is an iterative process and students need feedback on the previous report for the next submission and to continue to develop the model. Hand in dates at week 3, 5, and 8 along with feedback being provided within 7 days will facilitate timely feedback for submission of the final written assessment and presentation taking place in Week 11. All assessment is complete before the examination period.

The students will be developing their own models to answer a real world question. Utilising and developing their knowledge acquired through both this module and CHEM521 making this assessment format authentic.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically appraise how AI is used to accelerate the drug discovery process.
 LO2 Select and apply AI methods to analyse biological data and predict drug-target interactions.
 LO3 Design and implement AI-driven strategies for identifying and optimizing drug candidates.
 LO4 Critically evaluate the effectiveness of AI in reducing the time and cost of drug discovery.
 LO5 Critically analyse the ethical and regulatory implications of AI in drug discovery.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Synthesize and present findings from recent research on AI applications in drug discovery

Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc in Drug Discovery. It is a bespoke core module for the programme. There are no other suitable modules available.

Overview

Overview
This module explores how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the drug discovery landscape, enabling faster and more efficient identification of novel therapeutics. It provides an in-depth understanding of the integration of AI techniques with biological data to accelerate various stages of drug discovery, from target identification to lead optimisation and clinical trials. The module covers the latest AI-driven approaches and tools used to analyse complex biological datasets, predict drug efficacy and safety, and optimise drug candidates. Through a combination of theoretical learning and practical applications, students will gain the skills to apply AI in real-world drug discovery projects. The module is assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Educational Aims
To provide students with comprehensive knowledge of how AI can accelerate drug discovery including improvements in efficiency, accuracy, cost-effectiveness and integration with biological data.

To equip students with the practical skills needed to apply AI techniques in different stages of the drug discovery pipeline.

To engage students with current research and advancements in AI-driven drug discovery, enabling them to explore potential challenges and opportunities
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module explores how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the drug discovery landscape, enabling faster and more efficient identification of novel therapeutics. It provides an in-depth understanding of the integration of AI techniques with biological data to accelerate various stages of drug discovery, from target identification to lead optimisation and clinical trials. The module is taught through a mixture of lectures and workshops and assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Outline Syllabus
Brief recap of AI in Drug Discovery and the role of AI in accelerating drug discovery.

Introduction to machine learning and AI techniques relevant to biology.
- AI in Target Identification and Validation
- Computational methods for target identification (e.g., genomics, proteomics).
- Case studies on successful AI applications in target discovery.

Brief recap of AI in Lead Discovery (covered in prerequisit module CHEM521)

AI approaches for optimising pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties. including ADMET (Absorption, Distribution, Metabolism, Excretion, Toxicity) predictions.

Predicting off-target effects and drug safety using AI.

AI for Predicting Drug Efficacy and Safety

AI-driven preclinical and clinical trial predictions.

Integrating AI with Bioinformatics

Bioinformatics pipelines enhanced by AI.

Multi-omics data integration and analysis using AI.

Personalised medicine and precision drug discovery through AI.

Ethical, Legal, and Regulatory Considerations in AI-driven drug discovery.
- Regulatory frameworks for AI applications in drug development.
- Data privacy, intellectual property, and AI in drug discovery.

Current Research and Future Directions
- Emerging trends in AI-driven drug discovery.
- The future of AI in accelerating drug development.
- Group discussions on current research articles.

This module will build on material delivered in CHEM521. The content above will be delivered in 16 lectures, with the students able to access lecture material and reading lists through the VLE. Students will be expected to utilise the reading list to supplement the lecture knowledge in order to complete the mini-project that will be developed through the supplementary workshops and assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures: 16 hr

Topics will be delivered in 1 hr lectures to deliver the underlying knowledge on to tackle the chemical data scenarios developed in the practical workshops. Delivered by staff research active in this area - research connected teaching.

Workshops: 5 x 3 hr

Workshops will be used to give students practical experience in applying the concepts covered in the lectures to a variety of biological related drug discovery concepts (Liverpool Curriculum framework - digital fluency and active learning). The workshops will include elements of data retrieval and curation and the implementation of methods for data analysis and their critical evaluation and will facilitate the production of the various assessment elements.

A typical week will consist of 2 lectures with a workshop taking place every 2-3 weeks.
Delivery and assessment will involve multiple methods, recordings of lectures will be available to ensure inclusivity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
5 assessments - students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. A semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline:

Problem Definition and Target Selection Report (15%):

Task: Identify a biological target (e.g., a protein, gene, or pathway) for drug discovery.

Output: A report detailing the chosen target, the rationale behind its selection, and a summary of the relevant biological pathways involved in the disease.

Data Collection and Preprocessing Summary (20%):

Task: Gather and preprocess relevant biological data (e.g., genomic, proteomic, or chemical structure data) required for the AI model.

Output: A detailed description of the data sources, preprocessing steps taken, and the final dataset prepared for analysis.

AI Model Development Report (25%):

Task: Develop and implement an AI model (e.g., machine learning or deep learning) to predict drug-target interactions, identify potential lead compounds, or optimise lead candidates based on the biological data.

Output: A technical report outlining the model development process, including the choice of algorithm, feature selection, model training, and validation. The report should include how they would establish performance metrics and a discussion of model accuracy and limitations.

Lead Optimisation and Validation Report (20%):

Task: Use the AI model to optimise the lead compound for improved efficacy, safety, and drug-like properties. Validate the predicted outcomes using either computational techniques or existing experimental data.

Output: A comprehensive analysis of the optimised lead compounds, including a comparison with initial candidates and a discussion of the predicted ADMET properties.

Final Presentation (20%):

Output: Give a 10-15 minute presentation on the pipeline

Due to the mini-project based nature of the assessments and the need for consistent feedback and the ability to check this has been acted on the written assessments can not be anonymous. Presentation cannot be marked anonymously.

Standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy – the format of the resit opportunity is the same but different data/question is used, capped at 50% and will take place in the normal reassessment window.

5 points of assessment – development of the final model is an iterative process and students need feedback on the previous report for the next submission and to continue to develop the model. Hand in dates at week 3, 5, and 8 along with feedback being provided within 7 days will facilitate timely feedback for submission of the final written assessment and presentation taking place in Week 11. All assessment is complete before the examination period.

The students will be developing their own models to answer a real world question. Utilising and developing their knowledge acquired through both this module and CHEM521 making this assessment format authentic.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS770
Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc in Drug Discovery. It is a bespoke core module for the programme. There are no other suitable modules available.

Overview

Overview
This module explores how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the drug discovery landscape, enabling faster and more efficient identification of novel therapeutics. It provides an in-depth understanding of the integration of AI techniques with biological data to accelerate various stages of drug discovery, from target identification to lead optimisation and clinical trials. The module covers the latest AI-driven approaches and tools used to analyse complex biological datasets, predict drug efficacy and safety, and optimise drug candidates. Through a combination of theoretical learning and practical applications, students will gain the skills to apply AI in real-world drug discovery projects. The module is assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Educational Aims
To provide students with comprehensive knowledge of how AI can accelerate drug discovery including improvements in efficiency, accuracy, cost-effectiveness and integration with biological data.

To equip students with the practical skills needed to apply AI techniques in different stages of the drug discovery pipeline.

To engage students with current research and advancements in AI-driven drug discovery, enabling them to explore potential challenges and opportunities
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module explores how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the drug discovery landscape, enabling faster and more efficient identification of novel therapeutics. It provides an in-depth understanding of the integration of AI techniques with biological data to accelerate various stages of drug discovery, from target identification to lead optimisation and clinical trials. The module is taught through a mixture of lectures and workshops and assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Outline Syllabus
Brief recap of AI in Drug Discovery and the role of AI in accelerating drug discovery.

Introduction to machine learning and AI techniques relevant to biology.
- AI in Target Identification and Validation
- Computational methods for target identification (e.g., genomics, proteomics).
- Case studies on successful AI applications in target discovery.

Brief recap of AI in Lead Discovery (covered in prerequisit module CHEM521)

AI approaches for optimising pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties. including ADMET (Absorption, Distribution, Metabolism, Excretion, Toxicity) predictions.

Predicting off-target effects and drug safety using AI.

AI for Predicting Drug Efficacy and Safety

AI-driven preclinical and clinical trial predictions.

Integrating AI with Bioinformatics

Bioinformatics pipelines enhanced by AI.

Multi-omics data integration and analysis using AI.

Personalised medicine and precision drug discovery through AI.

Ethical, Legal, and Regulatory Considerations in AI-driven drug discovery.
- Regulatory frameworks for AI applications in drug development.
- Data privacy, intellectual property, and AI in drug discovery.

Current Research and Future Directions
- Emerging trends in AI-driven drug discovery.
- The future of AI in accelerating drug development.
- Group discussions on current research articles.

This module will build on material delivered in CHEM521. The content above will be delivered in 16 lectures, with the students able to access lecture material and reading lists through the VLE. Students will be expected to utilise the reading list to supplement the lecture knowledge in order to complete the mini-project that will be developed through the supplementary workshops and assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures: 16 hr

Topics will be delivered in 1 hr lectures to deliver the underlying knowledge on to tackle the chemical data scenarios developed in the practical workshops. Delivered by staff research active in this area - research connected teaching.

Workshops: 5 x 3 hr

Workshops will be used to give students practical experience in applying the concepts covered in the lectures to a variety of biological related drug discovery concepts (Liverpool Curriculum framework - digital fluency and active learning). The workshops will include elements of data retrieval and curation and the implementation of methods for data analysis and their critical evaluation and will facilitate the production of the various assessment elements.

A typical week will consist of 2 lectures with a workshop taking place every 2-3 weeks.
Delivery and assessment will involve multiple methods, recordings of lectures will be available to ensure inclusivity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
5 assessments - students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. A semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline:

Problem Definition and Target Selection Report (15%):

Task: Identify a biological target (e.g., a protein, gene, or pathway) for drug discovery.

Output: A report detailing the chosen target, the rationale behind its selection, and a summary of the relevant biological pathways involved in the disease.

Data Collection and Preprocessing Summary (20%):

Task: Gather and preprocess relevant biological data (e.g., genomic, proteomic, or chemical structure data) required for the AI model.

Output: A detailed description of the data sources, preprocessing steps taken, and the final dataset prepared for analysis.

AI Model Development Report (25%):

Task: Develop and implement an AI model (e.g., machine learning or deep learning) to predict drug-target interactions, identify potential lead compounds, or optimise lead candidates based on the biological data.

Output: A technical report outlining the model development process, including the choice of algorithm, feature selection, model training, and validation. The report should include how they would establish performance metrics and a discussion of model accuracy and limitations.

Lead Optimisation and Validation Report (20%):

Task: Use the AI model to optimise the lead compound for improved efficacy, safety, and drug-like properties. Validate the predicted outcomes using either computational techniques or existing experimental data.

Output: A comprehensive analysis of the optimised lead compounds, including a comparison with initial candidates and a discussion of the predicted ADMET properties.

Final Presentation (20%):

Output: Give a 10-15 minute presentation on the pipeline

Due to the mini-project based nature of the assessments and the need for consistent feedback and the ability to check this has been acted on the written assessments can not be anonymous. Presentation cannot be marked anonymously.

Standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy – the format of the resit opportunity is the same but different data/question is used, capped at 50% and will take place in the normal reassessment window.

5 points of assessment – development of the final model is an iterative process and students need feedback on the previous report for the next submission and to continue to develop the model. Hand in dates at week 3, 5, and 8 along with feedback being provided within 7 days will facilitate timely feedback for submission of the final written assessment and presentation taking place in Week 11. All assessment is complete before the examination period.

The students will be developing their own models to answer a real world question. Utilising and developing their knowledge acquired through both this module and CHEM521 making this assessment format authentic.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically appraise how AI is used to accelerate the drug discovery process.
 LO2 Select and apply AI methods to analyse biological data and predict drug-target interactions.
 LO3 Design and implement AI-driven strategies for identifying and optimizing drug candidates.
 LO4 Critically evaluate the effectiveness of AI in reducing the time and cost of drug discovery.
 LO5 Critically analyse the ethical and regulatory implications of AI in drug discovery.

Skills

The module covers the latest AI-driven approaches and tools used to analyse complex biological datasets, predict drug efficacy and safety, and optimise drug candidates. Through a combination of theoretical learning and practical applications, students will gain the skills to apply AI in real-world drug discovery projects. The module is assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Educational Aims
To provide students with comprehensive knowledge of how AI can accelerate drug discovery including improvements in efficiency, accuracy, cost-effectiveness and integration with biological data.

To equip students with the practical skills needed to apply AI techniques in different stages of the drug discovery pipeline.

To engage students with current research and advancements in AI-driven drug discovery, enabling them to explore potential challenges and opportunities
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module explores how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the drug discovery landscape, enabling faster and more efficient identification of novel therapeutics. It provides an in-depth understanding of the integration of AI techniques with biological data to accelerate various stages of drug discovery, from target identification to lead optimisation and clinical trials. The module is taught through a mixture of lectures and workshops and assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Outline Syllabus
Brief recap of AI in Drug Discovery and the role of AI in accelerating drug discovery.

Introduction to machine learning and AI techniques relevant to biology.
- AI in Target Identification and Validation
- Computational methods for target identification (e.g., genomics, proteomics).
- Case studies on successful AI applications in target discovery.

Brief recap of AI in Lead Discovery (covered in prerequisit module CHEM521)

AI approaches for optimising pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties. including ADMET (Absorption, Distribution, Metabolism, Excretion, Toxicity) predictions.

Predicting off-target effects and drug safety using AI.

AI for Predicting Drug Efficacy and Safety

AI-driven preclinical and clinical trial predictions.

Integrating AI with Bioinformatics

Bioinformatics pipelines enhanced by AI.

Multi-omics data integration and analysis using AI.

Personalised medicine and precision drug discovery through AI.

Ethical, Legal, and Regulatory Considerations in AI-driven drug discovery.
- Regulatory frameworks for AI applications in drug development.
- Data privacy, intellectual property, and AI in drug discovery.

Current Research and Future Directions
- Emerging trends in AI-driven drug discovery.
- The future of AI in accelerating drug development.
- Group discussions on current research articles.

This module will build on material delivered in CHEM521. The content above will be delivered in 16 lectures, with the students able to access lecture material and reading lists through the VLE. Students will be expected to utilise the reading list to supplement the lecture knowledge in order to complete the mini-project that will be developed through the supplementary workshops and assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures: 16 hr

Topics will be delivered in 1 hr lectures to deliver the underlying knowledge on to tackle the chemical data scenarios developed in the practical workshops. Delivered by staff research active in this area - research connected teaching.

Workshops: 5 x 3 hr

Workshops will be used to give students practical experience in applying the concepts covered in the lectures to a variety of biological related drug discovery concepts (Liverpool Curriculum framework - digital fluency and active learning). The workshops will include elements of data retrieval and curation and the implementation of methods for data analysis and their critical evaluation and will facilitate the production of the various assessment elements.

A typical week will consist of 2 lectures with a workshop taking place every 2-3 weeks.
Delivery and assessment will involve multiple methods, recordings of lectures will be available to ensure inclusivity.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
5 assessments - students are expected to demonstrate their deep understanding, higher-order thinking, and complex problem solving throughout - authentic assessment. A semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline:

Problem Definition and Target Selection Report (15%):

Task: Identify a biological target (e.g., a protein, gene, or pathway) for drug discovery.

Output: A report detailing the chosen target, the rationale behind its selection, and a summary of the relevant biological pathways involved in the disease.

Data Collection and Preprocessing Summary (20%):

Task: Gather and preprocess relevant biological data (e.g., genomic, proteomic, or chemical structure data) required for the AI model.

Output: A detailed description of the data sources, preprocessing steps taken, and the final dataset prepared for analysis.

AI Model Development Report (25%):

Task: Develop and implement an AI model (e.g., machine learning or deep learning) to predict drug-target interactions, identify potential lead compounds, or optimise lead candidates based on the biological data.

Output: A technical report outlining the model development process, including the choice of algorithm, feature selection, model training, and validation. The report should include how they would establish performance metrics and a discussion of model accuracy and limitations.

Lead Optimisation and Validation Report (20%):

Task: Use the AI model to optimise the lead compound for improved efficacy, safety, and drug-like properties. Validate the predicted outcomes using either computational techniques or existing experimental data.

Output: A comprehensive analysis of the optimised lead compounds, including a comparison with initial candidates and a discussion of the predicted ADMET properties.

Final Presentation (20%):

Output: Give a 10-15 minute presentation on the pipeline

Due to the mini-project based nature of the assessments and the need for consistent feedback and the ability to check this has been acted on the written assessments can not be anonymous. Presentation cannot be marked anonymously.

Standard penalties for late submission will be applied.

Reassessment strategy – the format of the resit opportunity is the same but different data/question is used, capped at 50% and will take place in the normal reassessment window.

5 points of assessment – development of the final model is an iterative process and students need feedback on the previous report for the next submission and to continue to develop the model. Hand in dates at week 3, 5, and 8 along with feedback being provided within 7 days will facilitate timely feedback for submission of the final written assessment and presentation taking place in Week 11. All assessment is complete before the examination period.

The students will be developing their own models to answer a real world question. Utilising and developing their knowledge acquired through both this module and CHEM521 making this assessment format authentic.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO5 Critically analyse the ethical and regulatory implications of AI in drug discovery.

Notes
This module has been developed as part of the new MSc in Drug Discovery. It is a bespoke core module for the programme. There are no other suitable modules available.

Overview

Overview
This module explores how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming the drug discovery landscape, enabling faster and more efficient identification of novel therapeutics. It provides an in-depth understanding of the integration of AI techniques with biological data to accelerate various stages of drug discovery, from target identification to lead optimisation and clinical trials. The module covers the latest AI-driven approaches and tools used to analyse complex biological datasets, predict drug efficacy and safety, and optimise drug candidates. Through a combination of theoretical learning and practical applications, students will gain the skills to apply AI in real-world drug discovery projects. The module is assessed through a semester long project around designing an AI driven drug discovery pipeline where the students will write four different output reports over the course of the semester on different aspects of the pipeline. There is also a final presentation.
Educational Aims
To provide students with comprehensive knowledge of how AI can accelerate drug discovery including improvements in efficiency, accuracy, cost-effectiveness and integration with biological data.

To equip students with the practical skills needed to apply AI techniques in different stages of the drug discovery pipeline.

To engage students with current research and advancements in AI-driven drug discovery, enabling them to explore potential challenges and opportunities
